content: Risk adjustment is the process of adjusting payments to health insurance plans based on the risk characteristics of enrollees. For example, payments can be adjusted to reflect higher costs for women compared to men, ensuring insurers are not financially incentivized to enroll one gender over the other. The mechanism for leveling the playing field in risk adjustment involves paying insurers $100 more for women than for men, or $100 less for men than for women, to reflect their different expected health expenditures. Risk adjustment models consider factors like age, geography, health status, and tobacco use, but still do not fully explain variations in healthcare spending. This report also discusses how CMS pays private health plans under Medicare Advantage. The report discusses how CMS pays private health plans under Medicare Advantage, including risk adjustment models that consider factors like age, geography, health status, and tobacco use. Medicare Advantage offers private plan options for Medicare beneficiaries enrolled in both Medicare Parts A and B. Risk-adjusted MA payments are made to private health plans under Medicare Advantage, which offer managed care options for beneficiaries enrolled in Medicare Parts A and B. Health plans receive a capitated monthly payment adjusted for demographics and health status of enrollees. Plans are at-risk if costs exceed payments but can retain savings if costs are lower. Payments are based on each plan's bid compared to the maximum federal payment for benefits provided. CMS sets a benchmark for bids, with plans receiving a base rate equal to the benchmark if their bid is above it, and a base rate equal to their bid if it is below the benchmark. There are over 13,000 codes that are mapped into diagnostic groups and condition categories. These categories have a hierarchy where only the most significant manifestation of a disease is coded for payment purposes. For example, Ischemic Heart Disease codes are organized into the Coronary Artery Disease hierarchy based on clinical severity and cost. The hierarchy of condition categories for Medicare reimbursement dictates that only the most severe manifestation of a disease is coded for payment. This ensures that the most costly form of the disease determines reimbursement. CMS audits Medicare Advantage plans to ensure that risk-adjusted payments are supported by medical records. Previously, audits only sought to recover errors in payments for sampled enrollees, but in February 2011, the President's FY2011 budget proposed extrapolating the error rate to the entire plan contract, resulting in estimated savings of $2.27 billion. In February 2012, CMS finalized the payment error calculation methodology for Medicare Advantage plans, allowing for the extrapolation of audit findings to estimate payment errors for the entire contract. Audits are conducted at the contract level, with a three-step process involving sampling, medical record review, and error rate calculation/payment adjustment. The history of Part C risk adjustment payments to private plans under Medicare involves various models that have evolved in complexity over time. These models aim to account for the variation in healthcare costs among Medicare beneficiaries. The R2 measure is used to assess how well each model predicts individual beneficiary expenditures. The R2 measure is used to assess how well Medicare private plan payment models predict individual beneficiary expenditures, ranging from $0 for healthy beneficiaries to hundreds of thousands for ill beneficiaries. The models aim to predict spending based on beneficiary characteristics, with the Average Adjusted Per Capita Cost (AAPCC) model having an R2 value. The R2 measure quantifies how well Medicare private plan payment models predict individual beneficiary expenditures based on their characteristics. The AAPCC model has an R2 of 0.0077, explaining 0.77% of the expenditure variation. Subsequent models have increased this percentage, with the most recent proposed model explaining approximately 12.5% of the variation in expenditures. The AAPCC model, prior to 2000, adjusted private plan payments under Medicare programs for demographic characteristics like age, sex, Medicaid enrollment, and more. These variables explained less than 1% of expenditure variation. The model did not consider health costs or adjust for enrolling very ill beneficiaries. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 required CMS to implement a risk adjustment methodology that took into account beneficiary health status by no later than January 1, 2000, using the Principal Inpatient Diagnostic Cost Group (PIP-DCG) model. This model considered demographic variables and beneficiary health to determine private plan payments under Medicare programs. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 mandated CMS to implement a risk adjustment methodology by January 1, 2000, using the Principal Inpatient Diagnostic Cost Group (PIP-DCG) model. This model considered beneficiary health status and the worst principal inpatient diagnosis for payment calculations. The PIP-DCG model explained more of the variation in Medicare expenditures than the AAPCC model but had limitations such as not accounting for illnesses with high costs that did not require hospital admission. Additionally, efforts to reduce hospital admissions could lead to lower risk-adjusted payments. The PIP-DCG model, mandated by the Balanced Budget Act of 1997, aimed to adjust Medicare plan payments based on beneficiary health status and principal inpatient diagnosis. While it explained more expenditure variation than the AAPCC model, it had limitations like not counting high-cost illnesses not requiring hospital admission. Subsequent legislation maintained a 90% demographic-only method/10% PIP-DCG method phase-in schedule until 2003 to ease the financial impact on M+C organizations. In 2004, the CMS-HCC model was introduced, incorporating data from various healthcare settings to adjust Medicare payments. Starting in 2004, Medicare plan payments were adjusted by the CMS-HCC model, which considers severity of illness, accumulated effects of multiple diseases, and interactive effects. The model explains nearly 10% of expenditure variation and is detailed in the "Risk Adjustment Under Medicare Advantage" section. Updates to the CMS-HCC retain the basic structure. The CMS-HCC model adjusts Medicare plan payments based on severity of illness, multiple diseases, and interactive effects. Updates to the model, such as Version 12 and Version 21, include recalibration with recent diagnosis and expenditure data to better explain variations in Medicare expenditures. The update to Version 21 of the CMS-HCC model increased the predictive power to approximately 12.5% by including updates to diagnosis codes and recalibration with recent data. This version underwent a major clinical revision in 2009 to adjust for changes in disease patterns, treatment methods, and coding practices. Version 21 is set to be implemented in 2012 for PACE plans.
